div3.head:
Southern
Button manufactory of Rowyer & Levasseur, New Orleans and Richmond.
div3.p:
The attention of the public is respectfully solicited to the stock of Southern-made Buttons of Messrs. Rowyer & Levassbur, which are of superior manufacture, made in good, workman-like manner, equal to those of any foreign manufacture.
They consist of
Staff Buttons, for General Officers, Officers of the General Staff, and Aide-de-camp.
Engineers' Buttons, for Officers of the Corps of Engineers.
Buttons for Officers and enlisted men of Artillery, Infantry, Riflemen, and Cavalry.
Confederate Naval Buttons, of all sizes and designs.
Buttons for the Staff and enlisted men of Virginia and various other States.

The above Buttons are of large and small size, and are the Confederate Button in every sense of the word, made precisely after the style adopted by the Confederate Government, exact according to the designs, in gilt, shape and size, to the highest degree of perfection.

Our manufactory is in the city of New Orleans, No. 135 Charters street: Mr. C. Rowyer conducting the manufacturing department in that city, and Mr. H. Levassbur attending to the sale of the Buttons in this city, to whom all orders from this city and State, the States of North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia, must be sent.
Our prices are as moderate as existing circumstances will admit.
Orders from a distance will be promptly attended to.
Our terms are exclusively cash, on delivery.
All orders from a distance must be accompanied with money, otherwise they will not be filled.

Those in want of such goods will do well to apply immediately, as the facilities of transportation are attended with considerable delay, and it frequently occurs that we are almost entirely out of some classes of buttons.
Call and examine our stock, at John F. Allen's tobacco factory, on Tobacco Alley, between 13th and 14th and Main and Franklin sts., in rear of Mitchell & Tyler's Jewelry Store.
mh 10--12t* Rowyer & Levasseur.

div3.head: Richmond and Danville Railroad.--Passports.
div3.p:
--Notice is hereby given that Passports will be required from all persons leaving Richmond by the Richmond and Danville Railroad.
No exceptions will be made, however well known the person or persons may be to the officered of the road.
Conductors are instructed to put off at the first station any person who may get on the cars without a ticket, or with a free ticket, unless he has a passport.
Soldiers under orders are alone excepted.
Chas. G. Tilcott, Gen'l Sup't.
Richmond, March 8, 1862. mh 10--1w

div3.head:
By the Governor of Virginia.
a proclamation.
div3.p:
the President of the Confederate States has called for forty thousand additional troops from Virginia.--This call affirms that "the exigencies of the public service require, in order to repel the invasion of Virginia, that her sons be called out in her defence more speedily than can be done under the operation of the law recently enacted by her Legislature." No call like this has ever yet been made, upon this State in vain.
Every nerve must be strung.
Every son of Virginia must respond with an ardent zeal to defend the Commonwealth.
Those subject to military duty are alone required to perform this service, but gallant volunteers, who come with the will to do or die for this great cause, will be given a place in our ranks.
This war has attained a point which requires brave men and true patriots to leave their homes and grapple sternly with the foe. We will not tamely submit to degradation or slavery.
We will have Virginia independent and all our liberties maintained, or perish in the attempt to secure them.

Therefore, I, John Letcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, by virtue of authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws, do hereby require the militia and the volunteers of the respective counties and cities named in the schedule hereto annexed, to repair forthwith to the respective places assigned them, without waiting for further orders.
Move at once to the places designated.

Commandants of regiments and companies will immediately cause their commands to be summoned, employing expresses where necessary, and when assembled, order them with expedition to the nearest railroad line, and thence to the rendezvous and report to the General in command.
Regiments will there be consolidated and formed into ten companies to a regiment, with one hundred men to each company.

Field and company officers sufficient for the force that may be assembled, will be assigned according to rank, and junior officers who have no commands will be considered supernumerary, and be returned to the ranks.
Officers in command of detachments en routs to places of rendezvous will cause the necessary supplies for their commands to be furnished, giving to the persons furnishing them certificates of indebtedness, which will be paid by the Auditing Board at Richmond.

Every private having a serviceable fire-arm of any description in his possession, or who can procure one from a neighbor not able to perform duty, will carry it with him. If lost, the arms will be paid for by the State.--Those who have no arms will be provided with them at the respective rendezvous.

The loyal citizens of the West and Northwest, in counties not herein named, are earnestly invoked to form guerilla companies, and strike, when least expected, once more for the State that gave them birth.
With stern resolve and manly courage uphold the flag and the untarnished fame of the Old Dominion.
Scorn the misrule of traitors, who, with usurped authority, are desecrating our soil with a pollution worse than that of the direst enemy, and execute vengeance upon the foe who acknowledges and sustains their treason.

Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Seal of the Commonwealth of Virginia, this tenth day of March, 1862, and in the 86th year of the Commonwealth.
John Letcher.

div4.head: Places of rendezvous.
div4.p: To report to Major-General T. J. Jackson at Winchester:

The forces from the counties of Morgan, Berkeley, Jefferson, Frederick, Clarke, Hampshire, Warren, Shenandoah, Hardy, Page, Pendleton, Highland, Rockingham, Augusta, Bath, Rockbridge, Alleghany, Botetourt, and Craig.
To report to Gen. Joseph E. Johnston, at Manassas:

The forces from the counties of Fairfax, Loudoun, Prince William, Fauquier, Rappahannock, Culpeper, Madison, Greene, Orange, Albemarle, Amherst, Nelson, Campbell, Bedford, Roanoke, Pulaski, Montgomery, Carroll, Floyd, Grayson, and the city of Lynchburg.
To report to General T. H. Holmes, at Fredericksburg:

The forces from the counties of Stafford, Spotsylvania, Caroline, King George, Westmoreland, Northumberland, Richmond, Lancaster, Louisa, Fluvanna, Goochland, Hanover, Henrico, and the town of Fredericksburg.
To report to Gen. Benj. Huger, at the city of Norfolk:

The forces from the counties of Patrick, Henry, Franklin, Pittsylvania, Halifax, Macklenburg, Brunswick, Lunenburg, Charlotte, Prince Edward, Appomattox, Nottoway, Amelia, Cumberland, Buckingham, Powhatan, Chesterfield, Dinwiddie, Greensville, Sussex, Southampton, Surry, Jele of Wight, Nansemond, Norfolk, Princess Anne, Prince George, and the city of Petersburg.
To report to Gen. J. B. Magruder, at Williamsburg:
The forces from the counties of Charles City, Sew Kent, James City, King William, King and Queen, Essex, Middlesex, Gloucester, Mathews, Elizabeth City, Warwick, and the city of Richmond.
The Militia of the following counties will not report at present, but will hold themselves in readiness to obey orders when issued by Gen. H. Heth, or Gen. H. Marshall:
The counties of Giles, Monroe, Greenbrier, Mercer, Pocahontas, Tazewell, McDowell, Smythe, Wythe, Wyoming, Washington, Russell, Wise, Buchanan, Scott, and Lee.

The Enquirer, Whig, and Dispatch, publish daily for one week, and all the country papers in the State will publish this proclamation three times.
mh 10--1w

div3.head:
By the Governor of Virginia.
a proclamation.
div3.p:
in conformity to an act of he General Assembly, passed on the 12th of February, 1862, the Sheriffs and Sergeants of he several counties and corporations in this Commonwealth are hereby required forthwith to collect all the Muskets, Pistols and Sabres, and other arms belonging to the State of Virginia or the Confederate States, now in the hands of persons within their respective counties or corporations who are not in actual service, and which have not been recently furnished to the militia for public defence, and to transmit the same to the Adjutant General of this State at the expense of the Commonwealth.
The compensation to the officers for the services hereby required, and the penalties upon all persons for failing to execute the provisions of the law, are contained in the act, a copy of which is here to annexed.
Persons liable to military duty, who are not in military service, or to whom arms have not been issued recently for public defence, and who fail to deliver up such arms, subject themselves to the penalty of being forthwith drafted for the war.

Given under my hand, and under the Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 8th day of March, 1862, and in the 86th year of the Commonwealth.
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
Secretary of the Commonwealth.

p.hi: to constitute a Corps more effectually to Collect the Arms of the State Confederate States not in actual service, passed, February 12th, 1862.

div4.p: Be is enacted by the General Assembly, That the Governor of the Commonwealth be, and he is hereby authorized and requested to require the Sheriffs and Sergeants of the several counties and corporations forthwith to collect all the muskets, pistols, and sabres, and other arms belonging to the State of Virginia or the Confederate States, now in the hands of persons within their respective counties and corporations not in actual service, and to transmit the same to the Adjutant General of the Commonwealth: Provided this act shall not apply to such arms as have been recently furnished to the militia of any county, city, or town, for public defence by order of he Governor.

For such services the said Sheriff or Sergeant shall be untilled to a compensation of twenty- five cents for each musket, rifle, sabre, or pair of pistols so collected and transmitted; to be paid out of the Treasury of he Commonwealth upon the production of the Adjutant General receipt for the said arms, with as order of the Governor endorsed thereon.

When required by the Governor to proceed under this act, it shall be the duty of the several Sheriffs and Sergeant's so called upon to give public notice within their respective counties or corporations, requiring all persons having in their possession any of the arms referred to, forthwith to produce and deliver the same to such Sheriffs or Sergeants; and if any person having such arms in his possession shall fail to produce and deliver the same within twenty days from the day of publication of said notice, he shall be liable to a fine of ten dollars for every such musket, rifle, sabre, or pair of pistols, to be recovered before any justice of the peace, and it the person thus in default, without sufficient excuse therefore, be liable to military duty, he shall be forthwith drafted into the service for the war.

It shall be the duty of said Sheriffs and Sergeants, whenever such arms have been collected by them, forthwith to transmit the same to the Adjutant General, at the expense of the Commonwealth.
And any such Sheriff or Sergeant who shall fail or refuse to perform any of the duties that may be required of him under this act, shall be liable to a fine not leas than one hundred nor more than five hundred dollars, to be recovered against him on the motion of he attorney for the Commonwealth, upon ten days notice before the court of the county or corporation in which he may reside.
This act shall be in force from its passage.
A copy from the Rolls.
[Teste:] Wm. F. Gordon, Jr.,
mh 10--sw8t C. H. D. and K. of R.

head.hi:
Adjt. And Insp'r General's Office,
Richmond,

list.head: General Orders, no. 11.--
list.item:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned.
proclamation.
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in cities threatened with invasion--
I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial law in hereby extended over the city of Petersburg and the adjoining and surrounding country to the distance of ten mile, and do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that of the Major of the city, and that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the said city and surrounding country to the distance aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, on the eighth day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
(Singed,) Jefferson Davis.
II. William Pannill is appointed Provost Marshal, and is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation, and will forthwith establish an efficient military police.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
mh 10--1w Adjt. and Insp'r Gen.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Elliott Grays,
Fort Nelson, Norfolk harbor,
March.--1862.
div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bossieux, 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response, and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.
div3.closer:
Louis F. Bossieux.
Captain Elliott Grays.
Henry Fitzgerald, Lieut., Recruiting Officer. mh 10--ts

Blankets are scarce, and, when found, costly, and each man is advised to bring with him one thick, warm blanket; also an adequate supply of under clothing.

For further particulars, apply to Sergeant James McDONALD, 12th st., opposite the Enquirer office.

div3.p:
I Am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished.
(this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve month's men can enlist with me. $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va. Address me,

An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

div3.head: Office city savings Bank, Richmond, March 8, 1962
div3.p: at A Meeting of the Directors, held this day, the following resolution was adopted and ordered to be published, viz:

Revolved, That in consequence of the inability of the Rank to use the funds now on deposit, the President be and is hereby directed to give notice by publication in the various newspapers of this city, to the depositors in his institution, that from and after this date, all certificates will be paid on demand.
Resolved, further, That upon all certificates of less than one thousand dollars, the interest will cease on the 1st of April, and upon larger sums on the 15th of that month.
Depositors will, therefore, please present their certificates, and receive payment.
Horace L Kent, President.

N. August, Cashier.
mh 10--1m ()

div3.head:
By Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auctioneers.
very valuable private Reeildevor on the North side of Leigh, between 8th and 9th sts., at Auction.
div3.p: --At the request of Dr. Walthall, we will sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 17th day of March.commencing at 4½o'clock, P. M., the very valuable Brick Dwelling located on the North side of Leigh, between 8th and 9th streets row in the occupancy of John Thompson, Esq.
The house contains 11 good rooms, with fire-places in each, and is supplied with every convenience, such as gas, water, (warm and cold) bath-house, &c.

The Kitchen contains 4 large rooms, and is supplied with an elegant Range.
There is also a large Brick Stable, and every other necessary out-building.
This is one of the most desirable residences now in market.
The lot fronts 28 feet, and runs back 150 feet to a wide alley, and is enclosed in front with a substantial iron railing.
Persons desiring a really valuable piece of real estate, either for a private residence or an investment, would do well to attend this sale, it being contiguous to the business portion of the city.

Terms--One-third cash; the balance at six and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862.
Jas. M Taylor & Son,
mh 8--td Aucts.

div3.head: Very valuable private residence on the East side of third, between Clay and Leigh Stress, at Auction.
div3.p: --We will sell, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 18th day of March, commencing at 4½ o'clock, P. M., the very valuable private residence on the east side of 3d, between Clay and Leigh streets.

The house contains 9 large and airy rooms, with fire-places, and all the modern improvements, such as gas, water, and bath-house.--There is also a large kitchen, containing 4 excellent rooms, range, smoke-house, and all other necessary out-buildings.
The entire property is in excellent order, having been thoroughly overhauled and repaired within the past two years. The neighborhood is as desirable as any in the city.
The lot fronts 98 feet, and runs back 130 feet.
Persons desiring to secure a really valuable private residence in a retired neighborhood, would do well to attend the sale of this property.

Terms:--One-fourth cash; the balance at 6, 12 and 13 months for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862. Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
mh 7 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Valuable Farm in Chesterfield county, contiguous to the city of Richmond, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises, Thursday, the 20th day of March, commencing at 12 o'clock M, the valuable Real Estate, on which Mr. C. H. Rhodes innately resided.
It contains 695 acres, fronting both on the Turnpike and River road.
The land has been recently surveyed, and will be sold interacts to suit purchasers.

To the Mission House tract there is attached about 100 acres, upon which there is every convenience for the accommodation of a large family.
The dwelling is befit of granite, and is in perfect order.
The out-buildings are also in good order.

The other lands are valuable, owing to their contiguity to Richmond; upon each tract of which there will be found a handsome building site, and nearly every one of which is well watered, and on some of them there are valuable gr ite quarries, and ice ponds.

Besides the main dwelling, there is on the land, called (Frog Level,) nearest to Manchester, a comfortable dwelling.
The tract will be subdivided into tracts suitable for suburban residences or market gardens.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added and recurred by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
mh 5 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Valuable Farm, in the county of Amelia, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell at Amelia Court House, on Thursday, the 27th day of March, 1862, (that being Court day,) commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the valuable Farm, located in Amelia county, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, four miles from Amelia Court-House, and near to the Amelia Springs adjoining the lands of Messrs. Powell, Cock, Jackson, and others, and now in the occupancy of Mr. N. G. Mann.
It contains 1,000 acres of land, one-half of which is in a fine state of cultivation, (upon which has been seeded 100 bushels of wheat,) and will produce twenty bushels of wheat to the acre — The remainder is well set in oak and pine timber of maiden growth.
The whole premises are well enclosed, and have an abundant supply of water.
The place is very healthy, and the neighborhood excellent.
The improvements consist of a large framed Dwelling 18 by 48 feet, and is ample for the accommodation of a large-sized family.
In addition to the usual out- buildings, there are four tobacco-houses on the farm, all of which are in good repair.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
Possession can be had at once, if desired.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
mh 8--2taw120th thendids Auct'rs.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Very valuable and well Located Real Estate, known as the "Arlington House," at the corner of Main and Sixth streets, for sale at Auction.--At the request of the parties interested, we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 10th March, 1862, at 4 o'clock P. M., the valuable property located as above, known as the "Arlington House," and now occupied by Col. W. M. Fry.
The lot has a front of 190 feet, and a depth of 162 feet, and has upon it the two brick tenements now kept as the Arlington House.
Each of these tenements has 14 rooms, besides large kitchen, and are finished in the most costly and elegant manor, with marble mantels in all the rooms, (except the garrets,) and mab doors to the principal stories.
After the of the tenements, there will be sold two cant lots--one lying east and the other west of the said tenements — each fronting 29 feet, running back 150 to an alley 13 feet wide.--These two tenements cost originally to build them, as we are informed, $48,000, and they are without doubt among the best houses ever erected in Richmond.
Their location, too, is in a most improving part of the city.
Terms--One-fourth cash; balance at 12, 16, and 24 months, for negotiable notes, interests payable half yearly, secured by a trust deed, The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
fe 27 Goddin & Apperson, Auct.

div3.head: Valuable Real estate on Main, 4th, and Franklin streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on Monday afternoon, (immediately after the sale of the Arlington property,) the following valuable real estate, viz: That remarkably well built Brick Tenement on the north side of Main street, near to 4th, and adjoining the residence of C. W. Purcell, Esq., now occupied by Mr. Watson.
The house has nine rooms, besides ample servants' accommodations.
It is supplied with gas and water and all other modern improvements.
It is admirably well located for a first-class dwelling.
After which will be sold a Framed Tenement on the east line of 4th, between Main and Franklin streets, in rear of Mrs. Dabney's boarding- house, having a front of about 35 feet, and a depth of 130 feet. After which will be sold that new and conveniently arranged Residence on the south side of Franklin, between 2d and 4th streets, now owned and occupied by M. T. Starke, Esq.--The dwelling has twelve rooms, is furnished with marble mantels, gas and water, and is very conveniently arranged.
Terms--Made known at the hour of sale.
Goddin & Apperson,

div3.head: The Richmond Varieties.
div3.p:
This quiet and orderly place of amusement, situated on Franklin street, next to the Exchange Hotel, is opened every night to the public.
The company is the strongest and most talented in the Southern Confederacy, and nightly give satisfaction to crowded and fashionable audiences.
The Orchestra is effective, and is under the control of Prof. Lorbman. . The company consists of E. R. Dalton, C. H. Morton, R. Ogden, C. T. Wolfe, H. Howard, W. J. Watkins, H. Michol, J. W. Moreland, C. Clifford, Peter Jackson, &c.; Miss Ella Wren, Mrs. C. DeHar, Mrs. Jennie Powell, Miss Louise Clyde, Mrs. E. R. Dalton, Miss Mary Partington, Miss Morton, &c.
Admission, 50 cents; Reserved Seats, 75 cts.; Gallery, 25 cts.

Doers open at 7 o'clock. Curtain to rise at quarter to 8.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p: --I take this mode of informing the public that, whereas a controversy has arisen between myself and Mr. Timothy Kerse, of Henrico county, growing cut of certain unsettled business transactions between us, in the course of which some expressions were used by me which may be considered injurious to the character of Mr. Kerse, I take pleasure in withdrawing the same, and stating that all the matters of difference between us have been settled in a satisfactory manner to both parties.
Robert Kerse.
Richmond, March 8th. mh 10--8t*

div3.head: Printing Office for sale.
div3.p:
Owing to the urgent call of the country for more man for the public service, I desire to sell my Book and Job Printing Office.
The stock consists of three Presses, in good working order, and a sufficiency of Types to do all kinds of Job Printing, with well filled fonts of Small Pies, Brevier, and Nonparell, for Book and Pamphlet work.
Any one exempt from militia duty can make a profitable investment by purchasing this office.
Make early application to George W. Gary.
Pearl (or 14th) street,
Between Main and Cary, Richmond.

P. S.--Previous to effecting a sale, I will execute all orders for Printing at very reduced prices from former charges, and solicit a continuance of favors heretofore extended to me, to myself, or to my successor.
mh 7--3 G. W. Gary.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 058, page 4.

div3.head:
[correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
Invasion of the Valley.
div3.p:
The Valley has been invaded by three hostile armies, all, seemingly, converging to this point.
On Friday last Charlestown was occupied by the column of General Banks's army.
The force at this time there is variously estimated from four to twelve thousand. Gen. Hamilton was in command at Charlestown when the latest authentic intelligence was brought from there.
General Banks had not yet arrived.
Several arrests have been made of citizens of Jefferson county.
On Saturday night two regiments of infantry, with cavalry and artillery, under the command of Col. Leonard, took possession of Martinsburg, in the county of Berkeley. Four additional regiments have since been added to his force.
Many arrests have been made in Berkeley — amongst others, Daniel Burkhart, President of the Bank of Berkeley; Geo. H. Murphy, States Attorney; Dr. P. J. McGary, Samuel Alburtis, editor of the Republican, &c. The enemy is in considerable force at Paw Paw, in the county of Morgan, and also further up the river in Hampshire. Col. Ed. McDonald, of the latter county, who arrived here to-day, estimates their numbers at ten thousand, under the command of Gen. Lander, (since dead.) This column of attack, has not the advantage of the McAdamized roads which the two others have, and is slower in its progress.

General Jackson with his gallant army to here, and presents the only obstacle to the entire occupation of this productive and Parfamed Valley.
We are daily expecting reinforcements.
Notwithstanding the powerful force now converging upon us, it is the unanimous wish of Jackson's army to meet them and try with them the chances of battle; whether they will be indulged in this patriotic desire, rests with the commanding General, and must depend upon events not yet ascertained.

The combined forces of the enemy at this time, in this Valley, cannot be short of thirty thousand.
Whilst its primary object is the occupation of this Valley, it cannot be doubted that it is intended to co-operate in movements East of the Blue Ridge and in the direction of Richmond.
Charlestown to the East, and Martinsburg to the North, are each 22 miles from this place, and Lander's forces to the West, about 30 miles distant from us.

div3.head:
Runaway--
$100 reward.
div3.p:
If found without, $50 if found within this State.
Runaway in November last, Jesse, a man about 24 years old. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches in height, very slim and delicate-looking, has been brought up as a dining room servant, has sprightly manners, is of a gingerbread color, has one ankle sprained and limps slightly, has one of his thumbs a great deal enlarged from a whitlow, and has rather red eyes.
The above reward will be paid if he be delivered to Mr. Ed. D. Eacho, or lodged in jail in Richmond.
S. P. Flournoy.
mh 5--6t

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the 4th Regiment Virginia Cavalry, at Camp Ewell, near Manassas, a bay Mare, six years old, star in forehead, thick set, in good order, bushy mane and tall, and one hind leg a little larger than the other.
Raise her mane and you will see where it has been trimmed underneath.
I will give the above reward to any one returning the above-described mare to me, or for any information which will enable me to get her.
Edmond Bossieux,
mh 5--12t* Lieut. Co. I, 4th Va. Cav.

div3.head: Ranaway--$10 reward
div3.p:
--From my house, on the 4th of February. Andrew, slave belonging to the estate of Mrs. Nancy D. Priddy.
He is about 5 feet 3 inches high, and black.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension.
mh 5--1w* J. S. Priddy.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday night last, two negromen, Isaiah and Charles.
Isaiah is about 22 years of age, black, about 5 feet 8 inches tall, quick spoken and quite intelligent.
Charles is about 45 years old, dark brown complexion, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, and not very intelligent.
They were both originally from North Carolina, and may be endeavoring to make their way back to that State.
I will give a reward of $25 for the arrest and return of either, or $50 for both.
Robert H. Styll,
mh 3--6t* Richmond city.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, had been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. B. Herst, and the train left him at Burksville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age, dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
J. W. Alsobrooks,
fe 17--1m* Mill Town, Alabama.

div3.p:
--This first class Institution, thoroughly preparatory to the University of Va., and also for the Engineering profession, whether Civil or Military, can receive a few more pupils.
Charges — from March 1st to close of Session, $140, for everything except lights.
Address for information the Principal.

div3.head: Oxford female College.
div3.p: All the Departments of this School are now conducted by teachers of the highest qualifications.
Students are admitted at any time, and charged from the date of their admission.

The advantages afforded, the low price of board and tuition, and the health and quietness of the surrounding country, unite in making this a very pleasant retreat for those wishing to devote themselves to study.
Inquiries addressed to "Rev. R. H. Marsh," Oxford, N. C., will be promptly answered.
fe 17--12t*

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p: --As I intend closing my present business in Richmond by the 1st April next, I take this occasion to ask all persons indebted to me to pay their accounts without further delay, as longer indulgence cannot be given.
If there are any unsettled claims against me, I wish them presented immediately, and will take pleasure in paying them.
I wish to purchase a young negro Sawyer, who understands sewing with a steam mill.
fe 11--1m* Truman A. Parker.

We have on hand many desirable Housekeeping Goods, Gold Band and Fancy Decorated Dinner Setts, Rich Gill Tea Setts, Toilet Setts, Bohemian and China Vases, Cut and Pressed Glassware, Silver- Plated Goods, Rich French Plate Mirrors, &c., &c.
Our stock of common Earthenware, though not complete, embraces many staple articles, which will be sold at low prices to the trade.

div3.head: To all whom it may Concern.
div3.p: Information having reached our ears that reports and rumors are rife in Goochland county, Va., derogatory to the character of the Goochland Grays and its commander, Capt. Wm. F. Harrison--such reports and rumors, tending to injure the above-mentioned company and officer as patriots and as soldiers, we, the undersigned, would fully endorse the conduct of said company and officer as gallant and brave, as far as observed by us, and as far as our inquiry has been able to reach, and hesitate not to give this our voluntary (unasked by him) certificate to that effect; and we believe such rumors and reports false and malicious.

div3.head: Southern Protection Insurance Company.
div3.p: --At a meeting of the Directors of the Southern Protection Insurance Company, held at Richmond, on the 20th of February, in pursuance of a resolution of the General Assembly, the following proceedings were had:
Resolved, by the Diresctors, That the office of the said company shall for the present be established at the city of Richmond.

That the several agents of the company be requested to communicate with the President, Henry W. Thomas, Esq., in reference to the business of the company, and that they recruit to the President the amount of their several liabilities as far as practicable.

Resolved That notwithstanding the occupancy of Alexandria by the enemy, the Directors have no hesitation in expressing their entire confidence in the solvency of the company, and its ability to meet its engagements, and to assure the parties insured in said company of their belief in the ability to sustain the Company upon its original basis, and to redeem its liabilities.

That the President be required to issue notices to all persons insured by the company who may have sustained losses from fire, communicate the same to the President with the proofs required by the bye-laws, on or before the 1st of April, in order that provision may be made for their payment.
H. W. Thomas, Pres't.
T. D. Hill. Sec'y. fe 26--dt1stA.

div3.head: To the Voters of the city of Richmond.
div3.p: --L. M. Jude, the clerk of the Night Watch, will be voted for as Captain of the night Watch, to take the place of the late A. Wilkinson, and will be supported by
fe 1--1m* Many Voters of this City.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--On 12th February, from Adams's Store, six miles below Richmond, a Horse or Mare, supposed to be a gray, and branded C. S. A suitable reward will be paid if returned to the undersigned.
If found in possession of any person, they will be liable to criminal prosecution.
Weston & Williams,
mh 8--6t 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the owner, on Wednesday, 5th instant, a fine, young, red Cow, believed to have at this time a calf by her side.
No particular marks recollected.
The above reward will be paid by delivering the said Cow to
E. B. Cook,
mh 8--3t No. 70 Main street.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--There was brought to my stable, on the 5th inst., a dark mare Mule.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take her away.
Robert Reid,
mh 8--3t* Stables 6th street.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--A Porte-Monnaie, containing one $5 Confederate note, one $1 note, (Monticello Bank, Charlottesville,) one $1 note, (Bank of Fayetteville, N. C.,) and some smaller notes, amount not recollected.
The finder will please return the same to
T. W. Keesee, Auct.,
mh 7--3t Corner 12th and Cary sts.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--From the subscriber's lot, 5th street, between Clay and Leigh streets, third house from Leigh, west, a Calf, about 15 months old, red color, with small horns, not marked, Devon bread, graded.
A suitable reward will be paid for returning said Calf, as above, or leaving information so that it may be recovered, at the office of the Religious Herald, 10th street, between Main and Cary. [mh 7--8t*] W. Sands.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Left the Government stable on the 16th February, a black Mule, lame and sweenyed.
Five Dollars reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
Wm. E. Warren,
Capt. and Ass't Quartermaster,
mh 5--2w Bank street.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--one hundred Dollars reward — Supposed to have been dropped when on the Richmond and Danville Railroad cars, on the evening of the 20th inst., a small black Porte-Monnaie, containing four checks, drawn by A. Vaughn, Cashier of the Farmers' Bank of Farmville, on the Farmers' and Traders' Bank at Richmond, amounting to the sum of $1,375, and one check of J. P. Leitch's, on the Farmers' Bank at Farmville, for $50, and five one hundred and two fifty-dollar Confederate notes, with some small notes and some silver change.
Also, some papers, memorandums, &c., of no value except to the owner.
The above reward will be given on delivery of the pocket book and contents to Mr. R. H. Liebell, Shockoe Slip, Richmond.
fe 22--d&swts Louis D. Jones.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, on the 18th inst., between R. Adam's Bakery, on Main street, and the stables of Davis & Hutcheson, on Franklin street, a Black Morocco Pocketbook, containing about $400 in notes of the Confederate States, Farmers' Bank of Virginia, and Bank of Virginia, &c.; also sundry important papers.
The above reward will be paid to the finder if returned to the undersigned.
Jos. J. White,
fe 20--ts At the Capitol.

div3.head: Lost — Coupons.
div3.p: --Lost in transmission by mail to Charlottesville, Va., the following Coupons of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad Company:

Interest payable in May and November, at New York.
All persons are cautioned not to buy or trade for them, as the same will not be paid.
ja 29--ts C. W. Purcell & Co.

div3.head: Lost--$25 reward
div3.p: --Between the First Market and Brooke Avenue, a
Black Bag,
Containing two Account Books and sundry papers, I will give the above reward for their delivery to me, at
Mos. 17 and 19, First Market.
de 21--ts John Lindsey.

div3.head: Freight to Lynchburg.
div3.p: Station's Line of Boats — vis:

The subscriber is Agent for the above line.
Boats will leave Richmond regularly for Lynchburg.
For the present, the subscriber can be found on the Basin, or at the office of Brown & McClelland.
mh 6--1w* Jas. R. Doss, Agent.

div3.head: Soaps, Soaps.
div3.p: --100 doz. French Toilet Soaps, very superior, just received and for sale by R. W. Powers,
mh 8 Druggist, cor. Main and 15th sts.
Balsam Copaiva and Chloroform, for sale in lots to suit, at
Meade & Baker's Drug Store,
mh 5 109 Main st., cor. above P. O.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 6, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders No. 4.--

list.item:
I. The proprietors of hotels and boarding-houses will forth with report to the Provost Marshal the names of all guests at their houses, and the names of all white persons in their employment.
A list of arrivals will also be furnished to the Provost Marshal twice every day, at the hours of 10 A. M. and 8 P. M.

II.
Livery stable keepers, and owners of hacks and other public vehicles, will report to the Provost Marshal the location of their stables and the number of their horses, hacks, &c. They will also make daily reports of persons from the surrounding country putting horses or carriages in their stables.

III.
No person is permitted to pass beyond the corporate limits of the city in a hack or other vehicle, or on horseback, without a passport.
Drivers of stage-coaches are specially forbidden from taking passengers at any point within the ten miles of country under martial law, either to transport them into the city or to distant places, unless such persons have passports.

div3.closer:
By order of Brigadier General John H. Winder, Commanding, &c.
mh 8--1w L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dept. Of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 5.--
list.item:
I. Colonel John C. Porter is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond, and Capts. A. C. Godwin and J. C. Maynard are appointed Assistant Provost Marshals.
All communications, verbal or written, concerning passports or the location of guards, must be made to the Provost Marshal.

II.
The city of Richmond is divided into two military districts, by a line commencing at Mayo's Bridge and running up 14th to Main street, thence up Main to Governor or 13th street to 12th street, thence up 12th street to the limits of the city.
The district east of said line of division is under command of Capt. A. C. Godwin, and the district west of said line is under the command of Capt. J. C. Maynard.

III.
Samuel Maccubbin is appointed Chief of Police.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig. Gen. John H. Winder.
mh 8--6t L. R. Page, A. A. G.

div4.p:
Wanted--one hundred men, for the above splendid Battery of eight pieces — Blakely Guns and Howitzers — to act as Horse Artillery, every cannoneer mounted; with Gen. Stuart's Cavalry Brigade Army of Potomac.
I am acting under the following orders:

"Headqes.
Cavalry Brigade. Centreville, February 27, 1862.

"Capt. Jno. Esten Cooke, Volunteer Aid to Brig. Gen. Stuart, is hereby ordered to proceed to Richmond, on recruiting service for the Stuart Horse Artillery.
He will be governed by the rules and regulations for recruiting of the A. and I. General's Dept. C. S. A.
div4.closer:
"By command of Gen. Stuart.
"W. E. Towles, A. A. A. Gen'l."

div4.p:
This will be the finest battery in the service.
It will be commanded by an experienced artillerist, a graduate of West Point.
Every cannoneer is mounted, with horse and accoutrements furnished by the Government.
The company, which is nearly made up, will be increased to 150 men, and as soon as the legal number is obtained there will be an election of officers, and the battery will take the field.

The ordinary bounty of $50 paid.
All persons wishing to join this company are requested to address me by letter, at Richmond, or apply at the Recruiting Office, opposite Goddin's Hall, 11th street, to me or to Robert D. Ward, Esq., who is associated with me.

div3.head: Adj't and Inspector General's Office, Richmond, March 7th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 10.

General Orders, No. 9, issued March 1st, 1862, proclaiming the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city of Richmond, within the city and the surrounding country to the distance of ten miles, is hereby so modified as to permit the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, and the qualification of guardians to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and order the payment of county dues.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War:
(Signed,) S. Cooper,
mh 8--1w Adj't. and Inspector Gen'l.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--All members of the Hanover Artillery now at home on furlough are required, by order of Major-General Magruder, to return to their company immediately.
All who are absent from the company on account of sickness, must return, if able to do any duty.
All recruits for the company will apply to me, at my residence, where they will be mustered in and receive certificates to enable them to get transportation free.
They will receive the usual bounty of $50 when they reach the company.
div3.closer:
Wm. M. Fontaine,
Lieut. and Recruiting Officer
mh 8--3t* for Hanover Artillery.

div3.head:
Rally!
Rally!! Rally!!!
div3.p:
--Recruits wanted for the oldest Regiment of Volunteers in the C. S. Army!--Company B, of the 1st Virginia Regiment, having re-enlisted for the war, a number of recruits are desired to fill up its ranks to the full extent of the law. Fifty recruits will be at once received on application to the undersigned.--Fifty Dollars bounty will be paid immediately on enlisting, and subsistence and transportation will also be furnished.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Lieut. W. W. Harrison,
Recruiting Officer,
At No. 8 Tenth st., bet. Main and Cary.
mh 8--6t

div3.head: Adj't Gen'ls Office, March 7, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders.--The Governor having been informed that in some instances the Boards appointed to decide upon claims for exemption have exempted persons not authorized by law, and the duties of that Board being clearly defined — Ordered, that commandants of regiments do not regard any exemptions which are not authorized by the act of Assembly declaring who shall be exempt.
div3.closer:
By command. Wm. H. Richardson, A. G.
mh 8--3t

div3.head: Young Guard.--Recruits Wanted.
div3.p:
This Company having decided to re-enlist, want about thirty recruits.
Old members and others wishing to go into the service with this well known company, will leave their names at my office.
Recruits will receive the bounty of 50 dollars, uniforms and equipments furnished free.
div3.closer:
Wm. A. Charters,
Office on 11th, between Main and Bank sts.
mh 8--3t*

div3.head: Virginia Rangers.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to join a Cavalry Corps, in which the hours off duty may be spent in agreeable companionship, are invited to enlist in this one. Twenty recruits will be received if immediate application be made at No. 39, Powhatan House, or at Camp Mercer, Fredericksburg.
None but men of unexceptional able character and habits need apply.
div3.closer: mh 8--1w* B. B. Douglas, Capt.

div3.head: Confederate States of America, Quartermaster's Office, Richmond, Va., 7th March, 1862.
div3.p: to Railroads.--To facilitate the transfer of Recruits from Recruiting stations to their Regiments, officers of railroad companies are notified that the Recruiting Officers are authorized to give orders of transportation for their recruits, and such orders or certificates of transportation given by the persons in charge of the recruits, will be acknowledged as sufficient vouchers for payment.
div3.closer:
Larkin Smith.
mh 8--10t Ass't Q. M. Gen.

div3.p:
All Recruits of Thomas's Artillery will report at my office, on Main between 20th and 21st streets, at once.
All failing to do so will be advertised.
div3.closer:
Lt. E. J. Anderson,
mh 8--2t* Recruiting Officer.

div4.p: Those wishing to learn the practice of the Sabre, mounted or dismounted exercises, or Lance exercise, can hear of a thorough, practical instructor, who was taught in one of the first military depots in Europe, and who served there for some years as a commissioned officer, by addressing
Cavalry troops in any part of the State will be instructed in the above-named exercises on immediate application of their Captains.
mh 5--1w

div3.head: Richmond Fayette Artillery.
div3.p:
--Having reorganized and re-enlisted for two years, is desirous of receiving forty additional recruits, to raise the company to the number of one hundred and fifty.
The battery is composed of four brass six-pounders and two rifle guns, and is among the finest in the Confederate army.
The Fayette Artillery is one of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to each recruit.
Only men of respectability, courage, and patriotism, are, however, required.
For further particulars apply to Peyton Johnston, 115 Main street, Richmond, or to the undersigned, at Yorktown.
div3.closer:
M. C. Macon,
mh 4--6t Capt. R. F. A.

div3.head: Adj't and Insp'r Gen's Office, [Extract] Richmond, March 5, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 51:
the regulations concerning Substitutes in the Army, dated October 20, 1861, are hereby revoked.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno. Withers,
mh 5--6t Ass't Adj't Gen'l.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p: Persons wishing to join the Maryland Cavalry will call at the office, corner Pearl and Main sts.
div3.closer:
Lieut. R. Brown,
mh 6--8t* Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: Headquarters Department of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 4, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 3.--
list.item: I. By virtue of authority conferred by General Orders, No. 3, Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, March 1st, 1862, Captain A. C. Godwin is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond and the adjoining and surrounding country for the distance of ten miles.

II.
The Passport Office is continued at its present location, under the charge of the Provost Marshal.

III.
The distillation and distribution of vinous, spirituous, and malt liquors, or other intoxicating beverage, is absolutely prohibited.
This order will be strictly enforced by the Provost Marshal against all persons found distilling, selling, giving away, or in any manner disposing of such beverages.

IV.
All persons, of every degree, except those in the service of the State or Confederate States, having arms in their possession will deliver the same to the Ordnance Department on or before the 5th of March, 1862; otherwise they will be seized and taken possession of by the Provost Marshal.
Arms belonging to the State of Virginia will be delivered to Colonel Dimmock, at the State Arsenal, in this city.
The word arms embraces in its meaning swords, bayonets, rifles, double-barrel shot guns, and pistols of such size as may be useful in the field.
Compensation will be made for private arms delivered up or taken for public use, and Government arms, not in the public service, will be receipted for.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. Jno. H. Winder,
Commanding, &c.; L. R. Page,
mh 5--1w Ass't. Adj't. General.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 3, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 2.
list.item: I. Officers in this city not on duty will immediately report and register their names at these Headquarters, corner of Broad and Ninth streets.

II.
Officers and soldiers in this Department must remain at their respective posts, and if found absent, without written permissions from the Commander of their posts, they will be arrested.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder,
Commanding, &c.
L. R. Page,
mh 4--1w Ass't Adjutant-Gen.

div4.p: Having been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.
Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies, for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance Company, Main street. City Post- Office, Box 877.
I have the promise of Armstrong field pieces; and should it be realized, this regiment will enter the field as Light Artillery.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: A young man, of a military education, from Alabama, will accept a place as a Substitute
To any one willing to pay a good price.
div3.closer:
Apply to "H.,"
mh 6--4t* Box 872, P. O. Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Executive Department, Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p:
all Sheriffs and others collecting State Arms are desired to have the same boxed, marked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting, and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.
Approved,
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
City papers copy. mh 7--1m

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: Private arms that have been received by the State at its Armory, as well as all that may be sent hereafter, will be paid for within a few days.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
mh 7--4t Col. of Ord. of Va.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillerymen.
div3.p: --All who wish to join the Henrico Light Artillery, which is fully equipped and in service on the Peninsula, will call at the Clerk's Office of Henrico Circuit Court, in the basement of the State Court-House, where they can get information in regard to the bounty of $50, &c.
div3.closer:
J. H. Sands,
mh 6--12t* Capt. Comd'g.

div3.head: Artillery service.
div3.p: The undersigned are authorized to form a Volunteer Artillery Company,
To serve during the war, and have enough men Enrolled to Ensure the organization, but wish to increase the number to one hundred and twenty-five.
The uniform of the company, for officers and men, will be that prescribed by the army regulations of the Confederate States.

While organized under authority from the Secretary of War, the company will form part of the Virginia quota, and in the draft hereafter to be made each town and county will have credit for each member of this company from such town or county.
Persons volunteering herein will be entitled to the bounty as provided by the Acts of the Confederate Congress.
Apply, immediately, in person or by letter, to
div3.closer:
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
mh 4--6t* Chas. R. Darracott.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Artillery Company, which is partially formed.
Persons desiring to join the same will apply at the office of Bayly & White, corner of 12th and Franklin streets, Richmond; Col. Wm. R. Winn, Hanover; or to Major John S. Thompson, Ashland.
A bonus of fifty dollars given to each volunteer, and uniforms furnished free.
div3.closer:
Samuel T. Bayly,
Capt. Co. "A," 20th Reg. Va. Vols.
Wm. R. Winn,
Col. 74th Reg. Va. Militia.
N. B.--None but persons of good character need apply. mh 5--6t*

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--Two second-hand Hacks and Harness, in good running order.
Also, four well trained Hack horses.
A desirable stand and stable room may be obtained for the same, if desired.
Apply at once at the stable on 2d street, between Marshall and Clay, between the hours of 8 and 10 o'clock A. M. mh 7--10t*

div3.head: For sale--
div3.p: 400 lbs best quality Hops.
1 Mare, 5 years old, and Spring Dray.
20 bushels Wheat Malt, suitable for bakers
A. J. Byrne,
17t st., between Franklin and Grace.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A fine young Kossuth Stallion, five years old this spring.
He draws finely in harness, and is really as gentle as a dog. He may be seen at the stable of
N. C. Lipscomb,
On 2d, bet. Broad and Marshall sts.
mh 3--ts

div3.head:
Carriages!
Carriages!! Carriages!!!
div3.p:
--The subscriber intends giving up his storehouse by the 1st of May, and will offer for sale his stock of Rockaways, Buggies, with and without tops, and Spring-Wagons, which have been put up with great care for this market, at very low prices.
As he intends to sell every vehicle on hand, he would further state that all persons in want of Carriages, &c., will find it greatly to their advantage to give him a call, as he is determined to sell, in order to close out his stock.
John Does,
fe 25--1m* Corner of 9th and Broad sts.

div3.head: Peanut Oil.
div3.p: The above Oil has been thoroughly tested, and is equal to the best Winter Strained Sperm, both for machinery and lamps.
Price $3 per gallon.
Orders addressed to us will receive prompt attention.
mh 7--5t* Wilmington, N. C.

div3.head: Ground Plaster.
div3.p: Those in want of Ground Plaster, can get a small supply, at Shockoe Mill,
mh 7--8t* South side the Dock.

div3.head: Lamp-Black manufactory.
div3.p:
--Lamp-Black in packages and quantities to suit purchasers.
For sale by
Jos. R. Blossom & Co.,
mh 5--ts Wilmington, N. C.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--In consequence of the junior partner being in service, and I not having time to attend to the collections of accounts, will after the 1st of April, require cash for all meal on its delivery.
Vaughan & Aromne.
mh 7--sl Aaj*

div3.head: Overcoats.
div3.p: --A few more Overcoats for officers, privates and citizens, which we are offering very low. Those in want will do well to call early, Baldwin & Williams,
mh 8 316 and 118; Main street.

div3.p: A fine stock of New Orleans Groceries, well suited for sutlers' use, comprising--

And other things usually found in a first class Grocery house.
The public are respectfully invited to examine the above stock at
Dudley & Co.'S,
mh 8--1w* 72 Main street.

div3.head: Selling off at reduced prices to close business.
div3.p: On account of the difficulties in keeping up supplies, I have determined to close out my whole stock, consisting of the following articles--
Thomas Jones,
No. 8, Main street, Richmond, Va.
mh 8--1m

div3.p: 8 hhds. N. O. Sugar,
For sale on consignment, by

div3.p: 7 bbls. Coffee Sugar,
On consignment and for sale by

div3.head: Thos. Branch & sons, Petersburg, Va.,
div3.p: Offer for sale:
Ten hhds. New Orleans Sugar, receiving, and for sale by
mh 6--1w Dunlop, Moncure & Co.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--Being about to discontinue housekeeping, I have for hire by the month or year, a Girl, with a child eight months old. She is a good house servant, washer, and ironer, and tolerable seamstress.
Also, a likely Boy, 11 years old, for his victuals and clothes, where he will be well treated.
Apply opposite the Catholic Church, on Grace street, to John A. Jeter.

div3.head: For hire--
div3.p: By the month, Or for the balance of the year, a No. 1 male Dining-room servant.
Apply at once to Geo. J. Sumner,
mh 8--4t Governor st.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Two or three Gentlemen, or a gentleman and wife, may obtain board at a pleasant house on Church Hill.
Address Virginia, Dispatch office.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p: A gentleman and wife, and six or eight Day Boarders, can find comfortable accommodations by applying east side of 18th street, two doors south of Broad, to
Mrs. James H. Lewellyn.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Several gentlemen can be furnished with Meals, on Grace st., between 3d and 4th, next to the corner of 4th.
For further information apply on the premises, to C. Barksdale.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Ten or twelve gentlemen can obtain Board and Lodging in a private family, by the day, week, or month, by applying at the corner of 29th and Marshall streets, on Church Hill, near the Chimborazo Hospital, and beyond the limits of the corporation, at the reduced prices of $1,50 per day, $7 per week, or $20 per month, washing and candles extra.
fe 19--1m*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The death of my brother, Mr. Geo. W. Donnan, in December last, dissolves the firm of W. S. & G. Donnan this day. Any person having claims against the firm will please present them at once for payment; and those indebted are earnestly requested to come forward and make settlement, as I desire to close the business with as little delay as possible.
Wm. S. Donnan,
Surviving partner.
Richmond, March 1st, 1862.

New Firm.--Having purchased the interest of my late partner in the stock of Hardware, Cutlery, &c., belonging to the firm of W. S. & C. Donnan, the business will in future be conducted at the same stand in my own name.

Having recently made considerable additions to the stock, and intending to use every effort to keep on hand a full supply of all the articles in the Hardware line respectfully solicit a continuance of the favors bestowed for so many years on my predecessors.
Wm. S. Donnan,
Iron Building, Governor street,
Richmond, Va., March 1st, 1862. mh 8--1w*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Sealed proposals will be received at this office until 12 o'clock M., March 25th, 1862, for the delivery at Richmond of

list.item: 400 Hospital Tents, 14x15 feet, 11 feet high, 4½ foot wall, complete, with files, poles and pins.
4,000 Bell Tents, 5 feet 8 inches ridge, 8 feet upright, complete in every respect.
1,000 Wall Tents, 9x9, 4 foot, wall, complete, with files, poles and pins.

div3.p:
Bids may be made for any number of tents over one thousand.
Specimen tents, to which contractors must conform, can be seen at this office.
Bidders will state the time required to furnish the whole of their bids.
Payments will be made on delivery of each 500 tents, and the right to pay one fourth in Confederate bonds is reserved.
Bids to be sealed, enclosed, and endorsed "Proposals for Tents."

Bids are also invited for manufacture of such Cloth as the Government can procure into Hospital, Bell, and Wall Tents — the contractor to furnish poles, pins, rope, &c., and to give satisfactory security for performance of contract.
Specimen tents and specifications, to which the work must conform, can be seen at this office.
Bids to be sealed, and endorsed "Proposals for manufacturing Tents."
By order Quartermaster General C. S. A.
J. B. McCLELLAND,

div3.head: For sale — a Piano.
div3.p:
--Rare opportunity.--A splendid first-class Piano, 6¾ octaves, rosewood, and round corners, made expressly for a professional man, very little used, and only by a professor of music, is for sale privately.
Inquire fifth door from the southwest corner of 3d and Clay streets, for three days, between 12 and 1 o'clock P. M.
mh 8--3t* F. Seibert.

div3.head: For sale--
div3.p: 20,000 feet inch Oak Fencing Boards,
Six inches wide and sixteen feet long.
Just received and for sale by
E. F. Ragland & Co.,
Marshall street, between 3d and 4th.

run the blockade.

div3.head: $100 reward
div3.p: --A reward of $100 will be paid for the detection of the person or persons who, on Monday night last, willfully defaced and injured several monuments in the Hollywood Cemetery.
Thomas H. Ellis, Pres't.
Office Hollywood Cemetery Co., Richmond, March 6, 1862.
mh 7--3t

div3.p: We have on consignment and for sale low--
Apply immediately to
Redwood & Keach.

English Hair Brushes, genuine Shell Combs, India Rubber and Buff.
Combs; a handsome assortment, for sale cheap by
mh 8 E. W. Powers.

div3.head:
Wanted — Recruits.
Magruder Light Artillery.
$50 bounty.
div3.p: Any cannoneers, mechanics, artizans, or others desirous of enlisting in the Magruder Light Artillery, will apply for information to Stephen D. Yancey, at No. 44 Main street, under St. Charles Hotel.

This company of Artillery, organized by authority of the Secretary of War, under the command of Lieut. T. J. Page, of Gen. Magruder's Staff, will for the present be stationed on the Peninsula, and a number of recruits are wanted to complete its organization, to whom extraordinary inducements are offered.
The battery will be composed of rifled pieces and howitzers, with the best equipments on the Peninsula.

Apply also at the headquarters of the Army of the Peninsula, Yorktown.
mh 8--6t

div3.head: Wanted--Forty Recruits
div3.p:
--Being authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Heavy Artillery Company.
Usual bounty and clothing given.
Persons wishing to enlist for this service, which has many advantages over Light Artillery of Infantry, will apply at the Rendezvous, on 10th street, between Main and Bank sts. John T. Rogers,
Wm. F. Atkisson,
mh 8--1w* Sampson Jones, Jr.

div3.head: Wanted — immediately,
div3.p: Three companies, to complete Col. Fitz. Gerald's Regiment of Light Artillery, which is to be ready for the field in ten days.

This Regiment is for the defence of Richmond, Norfolk and Suffolk.
Guns, horses, and all that is necessary for a light artillery battery, furnished immediately.
Apply to
Con. W. B. Fitz-Gerald,
At the American Hotel,
mh 8--3t* Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:

Address "A. G. N.," Dispatch Office.

native Gold!
native Gold!

The highest market price will be paid for any quantity, either large or small.

div3.head: Wanted — Substitutes for the War.
div3.p:
Unnaturalized citizens, over 45 years old, healthy men. None others need apply.
Don't want any others to apply.
Come and know.

div3.head: Wanted — Substitutes.
div3.p:
We want four substitutes for friends in the country, and are willing to pay good prices for able-bodied non-residents.
Call at our office, corner 13th and Cary sts., upstairs.
mh 6--4t Barksdale & Bro.,

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Five hundred cords of Oakbark at the Richmond Tannery, on Brook Avenue, for which I will pay $8 per cord also, for Chesnut and Spanish Oak, and $6 for Red and Black Oak. Having purchased the entire interest in the above Tannery, I shall continue the business on the cash system in my own name.--Persons having Bark or Hides for sale will please call at the Tannery, or address me by mail, stating the quantity and quality of each.
I will pay the highest market prices for Hides and Skins, either green or dry. I respectfully refer to J. W. Beveridge or M. Altmeyer.
mh 4--cod1m* Louis Gimmi.

div3.head: Furnished House to rent, and servant to hire.
div3.p:
--A commodious three story House, in one of the best locations in the city, plainly and comfortably furnished, for rent or lease, to a permanent tenant.
Also, a good Cook, and an excellent house servant, to be hired.
Apply to.
mh 3--2t Goddin & Apperson.

div3.head: For rent.
div3.p: --A nice Basement room suitable for a professional man or lodging room, situated on Grace, between 7th and 8th streets. Apply to Wm. R. Pugh,
mh 8--2t* Shockoe Slip.

Large and well arranged Dwelling on Franklin St., beyond the Corporation Line, for rent. --The large and excellent residence, located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Robert A. Lancaster.
The house has nine rooms, exclusive of the basement, with a large kitchen, stable, a well of good water, and a garden attached to the premises.
For terms, apply to Samuel J. Rutherfoord, Esq., or Goddin & Apperson.
mh 7--6t

div3.head: Cottage residence for sale, privately
div3.p:
--Corner of M. and 24th streets.--The Lot is well set in choice fruit; has a pump of excellent water in the yard, kitchen, wood, and coal-house, and every convenience on the lot to make it desirable.
Rarely is such a situation, both for health and pleasantness, offered to the public.
Call and examine.
mh 7--3t*

div3.head: For rent.
div3.p:
--For the balance of the year, my residence on Cary street, next to corner of 4th street. It contains three furnished chambers, one furnished parlor, one dining-room, with store-room and pantry attached; gas in all the rooms; kitchen complete with laundry and three servants' rooms.
Rent at the rate of $1,400 per year.
Address.
mh 7--3t* G. G. Otey, Box 889.

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--A fine house, with ten good rooms, on one of the most fashionable streets.
I will rent the house to any one who will purchase my furniture, which is very elegant, and of the most improved style.
I will also hire my servants.
Address, by letter, Post-Office Box 823. mh 7 --5t

div3.head: House for rent, and Furniture for sale.
div3.p:
I am authorized to rent out a House, on Broad street, near Brook Avenue, and to sell the Furniture at valuation.
Apply to
Thos. W. Keeses, Auct., office
mh 7--3t Corner of 12th and Cary sts.

div3.head:
Change of schedule.
Rich'md and Danville Railroad.
div3.p: On and after Sunday, March 9th, the passenger trains will run as follows:

Mail Train leaves Richmond, daily, (Sundays included,) at 6 A. M.; but on Sunday the train goes to Burkesville only, connecting there with the trains on the South-Side Railroad for the South and Southwest.
Mail Train leaves Danville, daily, (except Sundays,) at 9.30 A. M., and reaches Richmond at 5.20 P. M.
On Sunday there will be a mail train from Burkesville to Richmond, leaving Burkesville on the arrival of the train from the South and Southwest, at 2.20 P. M., and reaching Richmond at 5.20 P. M.
mh 3--1w Chas. G. Talcott, Capt.

div3.head: Wanted — Recruits for Morris Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--Twenty Recruits will be received into the above-named company, now comfortably quartered near Centreville.
The company numbers eighty men, who have been in service since the 19th of August. It is provided with a field battery and a good lot of horses.
Full uniform furnished free.
Besides the regular pay, persons enlisting for the war will receive a bounty of $50. Apply to C. T. Wortham & Co., Richmond; Dr. Geo. Fleming Wm. O. Winston, and Sergt. W. H. Toler, Villa Green, Hanover county, or address any of the subscribers, at Manassas Junction, care of Col. Wm. N. Pendleton, to whose corps the Morris Artillery belongs.

div3.head: Wanted — Recruits,
div3.p: For a crack regiment — the 4th Alabama, and Law's Legion.

The undersigned, having been appointed recruiting officer for the 4th Alabama Regiment, has opened an office in this city, at 109 Main street, (up stairs,) three doors above 14th, over Mr. W. S. Tupman's Furnishing Store.

This is an opportunity rarely offered for men desirous to enrol themselves under the banner of their country, in a regiment which has already won for itself a name for gallantry unsurpassed in history.
The $50 bounty allowed by Government will be paid upon enrollment in cash.
Clothing, rations, &c., furnished free.
I have given Lewis Warrington and John R. Plater authority to act as recruiting officers with me. M. B. Travis,
Recruiting Officer.

N. B.--Those desiring substitutes for the war, and non-resident parties who desire to serve as substitutes, would do well to call at our recruiting office.
mh 5--3w*

div3.head: Wanted--100 Recruits,
div3.p:
Major T. G. Peyton having permission to raise a regiment for the Confederate service, has kindly contented that the undersigned should raise a company to compose a part of said regiment.
I can be seen at all hours, day or night, at Battery No. 15. John F. Tompkins,
Lieut. Battery No. 15.
Any person calling on Lieut. Tompkins to enlist in the company which he proposes to raise, should he be absent on duty, will receive from me all attention in my power.
L. M. Burfoot.
mh 5--6t* Captain Battery No. 15.

div3.head: Wanted — Recruits.
div3.p:
For Thomas's Artillery.
Lieut. E. J. Anderson, of this company, has been detailed as recruiting officer.
Persons wishing to enlist in this company, will apply at the office of the Midlothian Coal Mining Co., on 12th street, between Main and Cary, or at Mr. E. A. Smith's office, on Main, between 20th and 21st streets, next door to the Georgia Dispensary.
The bounty of $50 will be paid on enlistment.
fe 17--1m*

div3.head:
Wanted!
Wanted!! Wanted!!!
div3.p:
One hundred able-bodied men, for the P. Army of the Confederate States, to whom will be given a bounty of $50, and $11 to $20 per month pay. The bounty will be paid immediately, and clothing and subsistence furnished at the same time.
Recruits will be allowed to join any company and regiment they desire.
Apply, immediately, at the General Recruiting office, corner Pearl and Main sts., up stairs.
C. W. Blair, 2d Lieut., and
mh 6--2w* Gen'l Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: Wanted--Fity Recruits.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized to raise a Volunteer Company, for the service of the Confederate States.
A bounty of $50, and uniforms furnished.
Also, comfortable lodgings and rations furnished to those desiring it. The company is to be commanded by a graduate of the Virginia Military Institute.

Recruiting Office at Bayly & Moncure's Shockoe Slip.
Also, corner of 17th and Marshall sts. Thos. J. Moncure,
A. W. Nolting, Jr.,
mh 7--1w* Julian Vannerson.
